tossups.question: Count Ferdinánd Pálffy attempted to secure the venue for this event by offering his theater for free, but lost out to the Kärntnertor Theater. Michael Umlauf served as the concert director for this event, which was followed by the dismissal of Anton Schindler. Henriette Sontag and Caroline Unger were recruited to perform at this event, which was originally intended to take place in Berlin. At this event, which also included a performance of the (*) Consecration of the House Overture, the composer kept tempo with his hands before turning around to face the cheering Vienna audience and bursting into tears. For 10 points, name this 1824 concert featuring the first performance of a symphony that sets Friedrich Schiller’s “Ode to Joy.”
tossups.answer: premiere of Ludwig van Beethoven’s Ninth Symphony [or the premiere of Ludwig van Beethoven’s Choral Symphony]
tossups.answer_formatted: premiere of Ludwig van Beethoven’s Ninth Symphony [or the premiere of Ludwig van Beethoven’s Choral Symphony]
acceptable: premiere of Ludwig van Beethoven’s Ninth Symphony
premiere of Ludwig van Beethoven’s Choral Symphony

tossups.question: In Ancient Rome, the pullus variety of this good came from southern Italy. Spanish nobility would sponsor trips on cañadas to the Consulado of Burgos, a center for the trade in this good. A medieval guild that controlled production of this good funded Michelangelo’s David. Approximately 13,000 people briefly gained access to political office following a revolt led by people who worked with this good who seized the Palazzo Vecchio in 1378. A guild of men working with this good was formed following (*) Florence's Ciompi Revolt; some of those workers used special combs when “carding” this good. The finest variety of this good was produced in England until the introduction of the merino breed into Spain. For 10 points, name this material shorn from sheep.
tossups.answer: sheep’s wool [or fleece; prompt on sheep or lambs; prompt on textiles or fiber or cloth or clothing]
tossups.answer_formatted: sheep’s wool [or fleece; prompt on sheep or lambs; prompt on textiles or fiber or cloth or clothing]

tossups.question: Otherwise “impossible” chemical reactions can occur at interstellar temperatures due to the domination of this phenomenon. It is difficult to mathematically describe this phenomenon due to terms with imaginary exponents caused by a negative E minus V term. The current produced by this phenomenon is monitored in an imaging technique that applies a bias voltage to a (*) conducting tip to analyze surfaces. George Gamow modeled alpha decay as this process in a symmetric well with heights defined by Coulombic interactions. This phenomenon corresponds to portions of the wavefunction that decay within the classically forbidden region. For 10 points, name this quantum phenomenon in which a particle passes a potential barrier.
tossups.answer: quantum tunneling
tossups.answer_formatted: quantum tunneling

tossups.question: A novelist of this ethnicity wrote of a doctor who unsuccessfully takes his wife to divorce court for 17 years. The memoir Red Azalea exemplifies the “scar literature” written by members of this ethnic group, which includes the author of Waiting. A writer of this ethnic background was inspired by the “talk-stories” of her mother to write a memoir subtitled in reference to her mother’s remark that all white people are “ghosts.” The Woman (*) Warrior was written by an author of this ethnicity, which is the ethnicity of June and her rival Waverley in a novel framed around their mothers’ monthly meeting to play a certain board game. For 10 points, Maxine Hong Kingston and Amy Tan are US residents of what ethnicity of the members of the Joy Luck Club?
tossups.answer: Chinese Americans [accept Han Chinese; accept Zhōngguó rén; accept Huárén; prompt on Asian Americans] (The authors are Ha Jin and Anchee Min.)
tossups.answer_formatted: Chinese Americans [accept Han Chinese; accept Zhōngguó rén; accept Huárén; prompt on Asian Americans]

tossups.question: In the 1960s, a key component of these devices was called the “Jesus Nut” by American troops. One of these devices nicknamed the Johnson City Windmill was innovatively used by Lyndon Johnson to draw crowds during his infamous 1948 Senate campaign. Arthur M. Young’s stabilizer bar was crucial to the development of these devices. The first mass-produced version of these devices was developed by Russian-American engineer (*) Igor Sikorsky. One of these devices titles Mark Bowden’s book about the 1993 Battle of Mogadishu. During the Korean War, a type of these vehicles called the Bell 47 transported wounded troops to MASH units. For 10 points, the AH-64 Apache is an “attack” version of what type of hovering aircraft?
tossups.answer: helicopters [or chopper; accept attack helicopters; accept Black Hawk Down; prompt on aircraft; anti-prompt on engines or rotorblades by asking “in what vehicles?”; do not accept or prompt on “airplanes”]
tossups.answer_formatted: helicopters [or chopper; accept attack helicopters; accept Black Hawk Down; prompt on aircraft; anti-prompt on engines or rotorblades by asking “in what vehicles?”; do not accept or prompt on "“airplanes”"]

tossups.question: The long nose of a seated man evokes the title of this painting per the artist's wife, who insisted that its title should be two words long. Critics debate which of the short stories "The Killers" and "A Clean, Well-Lighted Place" inspired this painting, which is believed to evoke Mulry Square. A popular parody of this painting by Gottfried Helnwein is titled Boulevard of Broken Dreams. In the background of this painting, two silver (*) carafes sit next to a yellow door. A woman with bright brown hair eats a sandwich in front of a bent-over man in a white hat, who is seen through the large window into the main building of this painting. For 10 points, name this Edward Hopper painting of a waiter and three customers in a café after dark.
tossups.answer: Nighthawks (The man in the first sentence has a “beak.”)
tossups.answer_formatted: Nighthawks
tossups.metadata: The man in the first sentence has a “beak.”

tossups.question: This scientist's graphical method has axes of volume, entropy, and energy and was among the first to use a surface to describe possible states. Though not the first to study them, this scientist popularized the partition function and statistical ensembles. This infamously verbose scientist knew that indistinguishable particles would resolve his so-called paradox, but no one could tell. This scientist's landmark work "On the Equilibrium of (*) Heterogeneous Substances" introduced his namesake phase rule. At constant temperature and pressure, change in chemical potential over a system equals change in this scientist's namesake quantity. Reactions are spontaneous if they decrease—for 10 points—what American scientist's namesake "free energy"?
tossups.answer: Josiah Willard Gibbs [accept Gibbs paradox, Gibbs phase rule, or Gibbs free energy]
tossups.answer_formatted: Josiah Willard Gibbs [accept Gibbs paradox, Gibbs phase rule, or Gibbs free energy]

tossups.question: It's not Las Vegas, but Charles and Ray Eames designed furniture for a nightclub in this city’s outskirts located next to the Belen Jesuit Preparatory School. A "little" version of this city hosts the annual Calle Ocho Festival and is renowned for cortado espresso drinks. A large steel sculpture modeled on an Alberto Korda photo hangs from a building in this city above a caption meaning "To Victory Always." This city was known as the "Playland of the Americas" when Meyer Lansky and other (*) mobsters controlled its casinos. A castle in this city's old town takes its name from the giant stone on which it was built, El Morro. This capital's fleet of 1950s-era taxis stems from a US embargo. For 10 points, name this capital of Cuba.
tossups.answer: Havana [or La Habana; accept Little Havana]
tossups.answer_formatted: Havana [or La Habana; accept Little Havana]

tossups.question: A man in this musical fantasizes about "chatting not about Heidegger but wine" in a song that ends by mentioning "tumbleweeds" and "prairie dogs." Its original creator wrote the autobiographical musical tick, tick… BOOM! a few years prior to this musical's premiere. Characters in this musical ask, "Will I lose my dignity?" and "Will I wake tomorrow from this nightmare?" before a scene in which a philosophy professor sings about his dream of opening up a restaurant in (*) Santa Fe. Two characters dramatically break up in this musical's number "Take Me or Leave Me." The cast of this loose adaptation of La Bohème reprise "Seasons of Love" after the death of the drag queen Angel from AIDS. For 10 points, name this Jonathan Larson rock musical.
tossups.answer: Rent
tossups.answer_formatted: Rent

tossups.question: A. S. Byatt's novel Possession includes one of these works titled "The Glass Coffin." Helen Oyeyemi's novel Boy, Snow, Bird is adapted from one of these works, many of which were popularized by Joseph Jacobs. Angela Carter's book The Bloody Chamber collects feminist versions of these works, which are typically assigned Aarne-Thompson numbers. Henry Fielding wrote a play based on an early English one of these works about (*) Tom Thumb. In King Lear, Edgar references two of these works by exclaiming "Child Rowland to the dark tower came, / His word was still 'Fie, foh, and fum.'" Robert Southey originated one of these works with his "Story of the Three Bears." For 10 points, name these stories that include "Jack and the Beanstalk."
tossups.answer: fairy tales [or folk tales; accept Tales from Times Past; prompt on tales or short stories or children's stories; do not accept or prompt on "fables"]
tossups.answer_formatted: fairy tales [or folk tales; accept Tales from Times Past; prompt on tales or short stories or children's stories; do not accept or prompt on "fables"]

tossups.question: American forces comically landed among sunbathers on the beaches of this city in Operation Blue Bat in 1958 after President Camille Chamoun supposedly requested US "assistance." Over 60 French nationals were killed in this city when a truck bomb struck a complex in its Ramel el-Baida neighborhood; that attack occurred simultaneously with a suicide bomb at a Marine Corps base that killed 241 Americans in 1983. Up to 3,500 civilians were massacred by Kataeb Party militias in the (*) Sabra and Shatila refugee camps in this city after the assassination of Bachir Gemayel (“jem-AY-yill”). This capital city was devastated by a 1982 Israeli invasion and a 2020 explosion of ammonium nitrate from the MV Rhosus. For 10 points, name this capital of Lebanon.
tossups.answer: Beirut [or Bayrut; or Beyrouth]
tossups.answer_formatted: Beirut [or Bayrut; or Beyrouth]

tossups.question: This denomination has been criticized for concealing child abuse through its policy requiring two testimonies before taking congregational action. This denomination's New World Translation of the Holy Scriptures translates the Greek word stauros as "torture stake" instead of "cross." This denomination gained its current name under its leader Judge (*) Rutherford, and its religious literature is published by the Watch Tower Bible and Tract Society. Members of this denomination believe that exactly 144,000 people will be chosen to serve as co-rulers of God's Kingdom, and meet for worship services at Kingdom Halls. For 10 points, name this controversial Christian denomination, whose members reject blood donations and proselytize door-to-door.
tossups.answer: Jehovah's Witnesses [or JWs]
tossups.answer_formatted: Jehovah's Witnesses [or JWs]

tossups.question: In Unix, the system calls brk ("break") and sbrk (s-"break") were the only way to manipulate this entity. This entity is filled in discrete frames from the top-down and continuously from the bottom-up. Only a clairvoyant process can eliminate thrashing when swapping pages in the "virtual" form of this resource. Segfaults occur when a program extends beyond its assigned segment of this resource. Calling the function (*) free twice can allow malicious use of this resource. Users who call malloc (MAL-ock) must manually deallocate pointers to this resource or risk a namesake "leak" because C does not have a native garbage collector. Using this resource is much faster than reading and writing to disk. For 10 points, name this resource that is stored in "random access" hardware.
tossups.answer: computer memory [accept main memory, program memory, data memory, virtual memory, RAM, or random access memory; anti-prompt on the heap or the stack before "virtual"]
tossups.answer_formatted: computer memory [accept main memory, program memory, data memory, virtual memory, RAM, or random access memory; anti-prompt on the heap or the stack before "virtual"]

tossups.question: Friend et al. found that almost no textbooks reported the “intense conflict” reported in the qualitative responses from this study and thus misinterpreted its conclusions. This study, first conducted at Swarthmore College, intentionally differed from the “ambiguous stimuli” of a similar study employing the autokinetic effect conducted by Muzafer Sherif. 12 of 18 “critical” trials in this study were designed to create a (*) “minority of one” in which 25 percent of subjects still always gave independent responses. In this study, confederates were instructed to lie about which line matched a “standard” in length. For 10 points, name this 1956 experiment conducted by Solomon Asch in which participants defer to a majority opinion.
tossups.answer: Asch conformity experiment [accept Asch experiment or Asch paradigm or Asch studies before “Asch”]
tossups.answer_formatted: Asch conformity experiment [accept Asch experiment or Asch paradigmaccept Asch studies before “Asch”]

tossups.question: Pausanias’s account of this event was informed by a trip to the temple of Athena Alea, where part of one participant’s body was kept. Hippasus’s thigh is ripped open during this event. Because they attempt a rape during this larger event, Hylaeus and Rhaecus are killed. The vineyard owner Ancaeus dies in this event, during which a young Nestor vaults with his spear and Jason kills a dog. A son of King (*) Oeneus engages in this event because his winemaking father fails to honor a certain deity. After this event, a participant gives his lover the hide of the central figure. For 10 points, name this event in which Meleager and Atalanta slay a countryside-ravaging beast sent by Artemis.
tossups.answer: Calydonian boar hunt [or Calydonian Hunt; or Aetolian boar hunt; accept anything about a boar hunt and the region of Calydon, Aetolia, or Calydonia]

tossups.question: Under this president, the reporter Paul Comly French corroborated testimonies given during the McCormack–Dickstein Committee. An executive order signed by this president created the Fair Employment Practice Committee, which effectively desegregated part of the defense industry. Gerald C. MacGuire allegedly planned to overthrow this president in the (*) Business Plot, which was exposed by Smedley Butler. The “switch in time that saved nine” ended the era of Supreme Court resistance to this man's policies. Hugh Johnson and Harry Hopkins led organizations meant to accomplish this president’s three R’s of “Relief, Recovery, and Reform.” For 10 points, name this president who implemented the New Deal.
tossups.answer: Franklin Delano Roosevelt [or FDR; prompt on Roosevelt]
tossups.answer_formatted: Franklin Delano Roosevelt [or FDR; prompt on Roosevelt]

tossups.question: In the closing passage of one novel by this author, a woman accepts her spinsterhood by sitting down with her needlework "for life, as it were." Another of this author's heroines receives a large inheritance from her uncle at the request of her cousin Ralph Touchett. In a novel by this author, Dr. Sloper takes his daughter to Europe to convince her to give up her fortune-hunting fiancee Morris Townsend. This author wrote of an independent-minded (*) heiress who rejects a proposal from Caspar Goodwood; that woman is manipulated by her husband's former mistress, Madame Merle. A novel by this author concerns the ill-fated marriage of Gilbert Osmond and Isabel Archer. For 10 points, name this author of Washington Square and The Portrait of a Lady.
tossups.answer: Henry James
tossups.answer_formatted: Henry James

tossups.question: The mu heavy chain found in these animals forms a tetrameric IgM and may be the heavy chain for the original antibodies. A "cone mosaic" of precisely organized rows of cones are found in some of these vertebrates, including a species that can regenerate its retina. Tinbergen found that the presence of red bellies triggers one of these animals to attack, in an example of a fixed-action pattern. One of these animals commonly used as a model organism has (*) transparent embryos and five distinctive horizontal marks that extend to its tail. 96% of these species have a bony jaw in contrast to their cartilaginous counterparts. For 10 points, name these animals that include species like the three-spined stickleback and one with striped fins named for zebras.
tossups.answer: jawed fish [accept teleosts or Teleostei; accept three-spined stickleback fish or zebrafish; accept ray-finned fish; accept bony fish; accept actinopterygii; accept osteichthyes; do NOT accept "jawless fish", "agnatha", "cartilaginous fish", or "chondrichthyes"]
tossups.answer_formatted: jawed fish [accept teleosts or Teleostei; accept three-spined stickleback fish or zebrafish; accept ray-finned fish; accept bony fish; accept actinopterygii; accept osteichthyes; do NOT accept "jawless fish", "agnatha", "cartilaginous fish", or "chondrichthyes"]

tossups.question: This novel begins by noting how its narrator is "stubbornly, scrupulously silent" about its events in a prologue titled "Naturally, A Manuscript." One character in this novel is entrusted with the task of securing the safe passage of Michael of Cesena. That character in this novel later finds a corpse in a pail of pig's blood. This novel's protagonist finds a mirror entrance to a heptagonal room called the finis Africae. The hunchback (*) Salvatore is executed by the inquisitor Bernard Gui in this novel, in which Jorge of Burgos eats the poisoned pages of Aristotle's Poetics and commits suicide by burning down a library. Adso of Melk and William of Baskerville investigate murders in a Benedictine abbey in, for 10 points, what Umberto Eco novel?
tossups.answer: The Name of the Rose [or Il nomme della rosa]
tossups.answer_formatted: The Name of the Rose [or Il nomme della rosa]

tossups.question: If inserting a word with this part of speech into a phrase results in an instance of the original phrase, then that example of this part of speech is termed "intersective." In English, when this part of speech occurs consecutively, those expressing opinions come first, according to the mnemonic OSASCOMP. Unlike in Spanish, English rarely uses the postpositive types of this part of speech, resulting in odd pluralizations such as (*) "attorneys general." The suffixes "-er" and "-est" usually turn examples of this part of speech into their comparative and superlative forms. When these parts of speech are modified to add an "-ly" ending, they usually become an adverb. For 10 points, give this part of speech used to modify nouns.
tossups.answer: adjectives [accept postpositive adjectives or superlative adjectives or comparative adjectives or intersective adjectives or participial adjectives; do not accept "participles"]
tossups.answer_formatted: adjectives [accept postpositive adjectives or superlative adjectives or comparative adjectives or intersective adjectives or participial adjectives; do not accept "participles"]

tossups.question: A rare type of this characteristic occurs due to a lack of the fucose-containing substance H, which is normally glycosylated with galactose or N-acetylgalactosamine to produce the defining features of this characteristic. Von Willebrand factor oddly carries the markers of this characteristic. Rho(D) is used to prevent a disease in infants caused by differences in this characteristic. This characteristic shows (*) genetic codominance. The presence of rhesus factor determines part of this characteristic. Not considering this characteristic before transfusions may result in agglutination and thus hemolytic disease. For 10 points, name this characteristic of erythrocytes based on the presence of surface antigens, including ones known as A and B.
tossups.answer: blood type [accept ABO blood type]
tossups.answer_formatted: blood type [accept ABO blood type]

bonuses.leadin: In 2009, a referendum to ban the construction of these structures was passed in Switzerland after the right-wing SVP ran an ad campaign portraying these structures as missiles. For 10 points each:
answers: Ethiopians [or Abyssinians or Aksumites; prompt on Blacks; prompt on Africans]
parts: Name these towers, which are attached to mosques and used to make the adhan, or call to prayer, five times per day.
This position is held by the man who recites the call to prayer from a mosque's minaret. Bilal ibn Rabah was appointed by Muhammad as the first holder of this position.
Bilal was from this ethnic group. During the Year of the Elephant, Muhammad's birth-year, a king of Yemen from this ethnic group named Abraha unsuccessfully invaded Mecca.

bonuses.leadin: Well into the 19th century, British Museum earned significant revenue from making casts of famous sculptures out of this material. For 10 points each:
answers: plaster [accept plaster of Paris; accept stucco]
parts: Identify this material. Many Baroque and Rococo ceilings are surrounded by decorative embellishments made of this material.

Jean-Antoine Houdon, who was fond of making plaster casts, made one of the most accurate portraits of this politician. Robert Mills designed a monument to this man that was the tallest building in the world from 1884 to 1889.
Hiram Powers used a pointing machine to create hundreds of plaster copies of a "slave" of this ethnicity, also the ethnicity of ancient sculptors such as Praxiteles.

bonuses.leadin: This character joins Colonel Arroyo's army after shooting a peso through the center. For 10 points each:
answers: the Old Gringo [accept, but DO NOT REVEAL, Ambrose Bierce]
parts: Name this character, who is later killed by Colonel Arroyo after he burns Arroyo's deeds to the Miranda hacienda. The Carlos Fuentes novel titled for this character ends with Harriet Winslow "sitting alone and remembering."
The Old Gringo is eventually revealed to be this author of "An Occurrence at Owl Creek Bridge" who disappeared in Mexico.
Arturo and Ulises search for the missing author Cesaréa Tinajero in Mexico in The Savage Detectives, which was written by this Chilean.
answers_formatted: the Old Gringo [accept accept, but DO NOT REVEAL, Ambrose Bierce]
acceptable: accept, but DO NOT REVEAL, Ambrose Bierce

bonuses.leadin: Lydia Diamond wrote a 2019 play about Toni Stone, the first woman to play in this organization. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this name for a variety of baseball leagues where legends such as Satchel Paige played because they were not allowed on Major League teams.
During Jim Crow, black performers traveled to nightclubs such as the Uptown Theatre in Philadelphia that were part of this informal set of venues, whose name is a play on the Borscht Belt.
Many Chitlin Circuit venues are included on the Blues Trail in this state. B. B. King and Elvis Presley were born in this state where Medgar Evers was killed.

bonuses.leadin: This molecule's derivatives affect biochemical processes like energy transfer and signal transduction. For 10 points each:
answers: cAMP (“C-A-M-P”) [or cyclic AMP; or 3',5'-cyclic adenosine monophosphate]
parts: Name this purine nucleoside which builds up in the brain during wakefulness, causing drowsiness, and is flushed away during sleep. This neuromodulator’s receptors are blocked by caffeine.
The inhibition of adenosine receptors by caffeine leads to increased neural activity, triggering the release of this fight-or-flight hormone from namesake glands above the kidneys.

Upon arriving at liver and muscle cells, epinephrine causes the breakdown of glycogen into glucose via a signal transduction pathway that uses this second messenger molecule to activate protein kinase A.

bonuses.leadin: Prayers were sent to this god to destroy three indestructible cities built by demons. For 10 points each:
answers: Shiva [or Maheshwara or Shankara or Tripurantaka]
parts: Name this god who destroyed the Tripura, or the three cities. This member of the Hindu trimurti is often known as the god of destruction.
The cities of Tripura were constructed by the sons of one of these materialistic demigods. Often interpreted as demons, they include the Daityas and oppose the daevas.
After destroying Tripura, Shiva is said to have performed a tandava, one of these actions. Shiva is depicted performing this action in his Nataraja aspect.

bonuses.leadin: Ann Deever possesses a letter in which her ex-lover Larry admits that he used one of these things to kill himself after learning of his father's treachery. For 10 points each:
answers: airplanes [accept more specific types of airplanes like fighter plane or a Curtiss P-40 Warhawk]
a tree [or an apple tree or a willow tree]
parts: Identify these things. Joe Keller tries to blame his business partner for manufacturing faulty parts for these things during World War II in the play All My Sons.
All My Sons is a play by this author of The Crucible.

All My Sons opens with the destruction of one of these things, which had been honoring the memory of Larry after he went missing. Desdemona sings "Her salt tears fell from her, and softened the stones" in a song titled for one of these things in Othello.
answers_formatted: airplanes [accept more specific types of airplanes like fighter planeaccept a Curtiss P-40 Warhawk]
acceptable: more specific types of airplanes like fighter plane

bonuses.leadin: This composer filled his music with 9th, 11th, and 13th chords to blur any sense of harmonic movement. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this French composer of "The Girl with the Flaxen Hair" and Prelude to the Afternoon of a Faun.

This orchestral piece by Debussy consists of three "symphonic sketches," the second of which is "Jeux de vagues," (zhuh de va-ge) or "Play of waves." This piece eschews motivic development in favor of colorful sonorities to evoke the interplay of wind, water, and light.
This Debussy piano piece imitates the Javanese gamelan with pentatonic melodies in its first movement, "Pagodes." Its third movement depicts a garden in the rain with flurrying sixteenth notes.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, identify the following about the Mayan economy.
answers: rope [or twine; or cordage; or cord; accept rope bridges]
parts: The Maya who lived in Guatemala’s highlands had access to this material, which was fashioned into blades and swords. The Aztecs made mirrors from highly polished forms of this mineraloid.

These luxury objects were traded by the Maya who lived in the rainforests. Many of these animal products decorate the war bonnets used by Plains Indians tribes, and other types were used to make quill pens.

In the 19th century, the Mayan Yucatan was a profitable exporter of henequen, primarily used to make this good. Structures named for this good such as the Queshuachaca (“kess-wa-CHA-ka”) helped Inca chasquis (“CHOSS-kees”) do their job.

bonuses.leadin: Along with kinetic energy, the three components of this quantity are constant in Poinsot’s (“pwann-SOH’s”) construction. For 10 points each:
answers: angular momentum [or moment of momentum; or rotational momentum; prompt on momentum; do not accept or prompt on “linear momentum”]
parts: Name this quantity that is equal to the cross product of a particle's position vector and its momentum vector.
Angular momentum is this type of quantity because it transforms like a vector under a proper rotation, but gains a sign flip when transformed by an improper rotation such as reflection.

When transformed by a linear map R, pseudovectors pick up a sign equal to this mathematical operation applied to R. This operation is non-zero for invertible matrices, and Laplace defined this operation as an expansion of minors of smaller matrices.
answers_formatted: angular momentum [or moment of momentum; or rotational momentum; prompt on momentum; do not accept or prompt on "“linear momentum”"]

bonuses.leadin: Feminist scholar Sophie Lewis's book Full Surrogacy Now calls for an end to this social construct. For 10 points each:
answers: Elena Ferrante [prompt on Domenico Starnone or Anita Raja with "under what alias were those books published?"]
parts: Identify this social construct whose "nuclear" form was pervasive in postwar America.

Full Surrogacy Now quotes a passage by this author comparing motherhood to being "a lump of food that my children chewed without stopping" from her novel The Days of Abandonment. Ann Goldstein translated this author's The Story of the Lost Child.

Lewis cites the hypocrisy of surrogate mothers being airlifted out of this country following a 2015 earthquake because they were carrying Israeli fetuses. Nine members of this country's royal family were killed in a 2001 shooting.
answers_formatted: Elena Ferrante [prompt on Domenico Starnone or Anita Raja with "under what alias were those books published?]

answers: language-games [prompt on primitive languages; prompt on games; do not accept "private languages"]
parts: Identify these linguistic concepts. The philosopher who created these concepts claimed they were related by "family resemblances" and illustrated their definition with an example involving colored squares.
The concept of language-games originated in Philosophical Investigations, a work written by this philosopher.

Wittgenstein named his Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus in reference to an earlier Tractatus by this philosopher of the Dutch Golden Age. This Jewish philosopher advanced a kind of substance monism in his Ethics.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer some questions about depictions of the Virgin Mary.
answers: maesta [or Maesta with Twenty Angels and Nineteen Saints]
Masaccio [or Tommaso di Ser Giovanni di Simone]

The shahada is written backwards on Mary's halo in this artist's San Giovenale Triptych. A red angel hovers above Adam and Eve in a painting this artist created for the Brancacci Chapel.

A large Virgin Mary dominates Piero della Francesca's Polyptych of the Misericordia. Piero also wrote an early treatise on the use of the linear type of this technique to create more realistic images.
answers_formatted: maesta [or Maesta with Twenty Angels and Nineteen Saints]

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, identify the following about Soviet Central Asia.
answers: cement [or hydraulic cement; or opus caementicium; accept concrete or reinforced concrete]
parts: The Bolsheviks formed paramilitary groups of this name to counter the revolutionary Basmachi movement in Turkestan. This name is shared by a faction of the Creeks that killed some 500 people at Fort Mims in 1813.
Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan were important Soviet sources of this resource. In the 1960s, the Soviets built the Druzhba pipeline to transport this fuel to East Germany.

Soviet-era Dushanbe was the site of a large factory to make this good. The recipe for the Roman "underwater" form of this good was lost for centuries. These days, it's often combined with aggregates such as sand.
answers_formatted: cement [or hydraulic cement; or opus caementicium; accept concrete or reinforced concrete]

bonuses.leadin: Caryl Phillips’s A View of the Empire at Sunset is about this West Indies-born author. For 10 points each:
answers: Jean Rhys (“jeen reese”) [or Ella Gwendolyn Rees Williams]
parts: Name this author whose best-known novel describes how Antoinette Cosway’s mother is driven insane by the burning of Coulibri plantation.
Antoinette Cosway is called the “madwoman in the attic” in this Charlotte Brontë novel, the jumping off point for Rhys’s Wide Sargasso Sea. Mr. Rochester owns Thornfield Hall in this novel.

Antoinette accidentally starts a fire after she is startled by passing one of these objects at the end of Wide Sargasso Sea. One of these objects is damaged after the line “out flew the web and floated wide” in “The Lady of Shalott.”

bonuses.leadin: Apocryphally, this object’s design was one of a hundred pitched to 3M by Sara Little. For 10 points each:
answers: N95 respirator [or N95s; or N95 filtering facepiece respirator; prompt on respirators, face masks or mechanical filters; do not accept or prompt on “KN95”]
PM10 OR PM2.5 [accept 10 microns OR 2.5 microns; prompt on coarse or fine particulate matter]
parts: Name these objects. Peter Tsai patented the use of electrostatic materials in these objects to promote interception and impaction, and un-retired to investigate their response to steam and dry heat.
N95s must retain at least 95 percent of airborne particulates in these two categories, named for their maximum diameter in microns. Name either category of particulates.
As mechanical respirators, N95s allow molecules in this phase through, meaning that one should have no trouble breathing in a mask.
answers_formatted: N95 respirator [or N95s; or N95 filtering facepiece respirator; prompt on respirators, face masks or mechanical filters; do not accept or prompt on "“KN95”"]
PM10 OR PM2.5 [accept 10 microns OR 2.5 microns; prompt on coarse or fine particulate matter]

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, identify the following about the House of Elzevir (“EL-zuh-veer”), which was prominent in the Netherlands in the 18th century.
answers: ciphers [or codes; accept answers like secret messages]
parts: The Elzevirs made their fortune selling these items. William Caxton was the first to make one type of these items in England.

The Elzevirs published Opera Mathematica, a treatise by François Viète (“vee-ET”), who worked on these things under two French kings. Leon Battista Alberti developed a tool composed of two concentric circles for creating these things.
Despite censorship from the Inquisition, the Elzevirs published Two New Sciences, a book by this Italian astronomer of Dialogue Concerning the Two Chief World Systems.

bonuses.leadin: Abraham Cowley popularized an irregular form named for this author, whose own poems follow a regular pattern of strophe, antistrophe, and epode. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this poet whose most famous works are collected in “Pythian,” “Isthmian,” and “Nemean” books of poetry.
Another of Pindar’s four books of victory odes concerns these games held every four years in honor of Zeus.

This later poet drew on Pindar’s style for an elegy in honor of the Egyptian queen Berenice’s chariot racing prowess in his Aetia. Stephanie Burt made Tumblr references in a 2020 book about this mentor of Apollonius of Rhodes who indexed the Library of Alexandria in his now-lost Pinakes.

bonuses.leadin: Crystal field theory describes how ligands split the energy levels in these elements. For 10 points each:
answers: d-sub-(x² − y²) orbital [accept x-squared minus y-squared]
parts: Name these metallic elements in the middle of the periodic table that have partially filled d orbitals.

For coordination complexes with this geometry, CFT predicts that the d orbitals will be split into four energy levels, with the d-sub-xz and d-sub-yz orbitals having the lowest energy. This geometry has a central atom connected to four others, with 90 degrees between each bond.
For a square planar complex, this d orbital is the highest energy because its density lies directly on the axes of the xy-plane.

bonuses.leadin: Attorneys at the law firm Sullivan & Cromwell sent out a memo demonstrating loopholes in a 2018 New York law banning the use of this process for harassment claims. For 10 points each:

healthcare industry [or medical industry; or doctors; or hospitals; or pharmacies; accept Electronic Medical Records; prompt on insurance industry]
parts: Name this alternative to jury trials, increasingly used by companies to prevent lawsuits.

In May 2018, the Supreme Court found that Epic Systems, a company that provides software for this industry, could use arbitration to ban class action suits. Epic has benefited from a 2016 “21st Century” Act that has provided federal funding for digitizing this industry.
This ride-sharing company founded by Travis Kalanick had at least 60,000 arbitration claims against it when it went public in 2019.
answers_formatted: mandatory arbitration [or binding arbitration; prompt on alternative dispute resolution or ADR or dispute resolution or reaching a settlement; do not accept or prompt on "“mediation”"]
healthcare industry [or medical industry; or doctors; or hospitals; or pharmacies; accept Electronic Medical Records; prompt on insurance industry]

bonuses.leadin: William Blake's print The Ancient of Days depicts the bearded god Urizen crouching inside a sun and pointing one of these objects at the dark void below. For 10 points each:
answers: compass [or pair of compasses; prompt on tool]
J. M. W. Turner [or Joseph Mallord William Turner]
parts: Name these objects. Blake also depicted a nude man in profile sitting hunched over on an algae-covered rock, holding one of these objects to a piece of paper on the ground.
That second print by Blake depicts this English physicist who co-discovered calculus.
This avid watercolorist referenced Goethe's rivaling theory of color in a work of "The Morning after the Deluge." John Ruskin championed this painter, who names a prize awarded by the Tate.
answers_formatted: J. M. W. Turner [or Joseph Mallord William Turner]
